item.title: Baldur's Gate 3: Best Cheat Mods On PS5
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Cheat mods for Baldur's Gate 3 make game tasks easier for PS5 players
  • Mod allows players to romance multiple characters without jealousy
  • Mods like Xp-Multiplier x10 help players progress through levels faster

It is often said nice guys finish last, and that the good die young. In this instance, the expressions might be changed to "the good die painfully and are turned into mindflayers" - which is not something that any player should want to see happen to their character in Baldur's Gate 3 . This game is by far the easiest of the three Baldur's Gate games, for what little that's worth considering the first two were niche CRPGs and this is one of the biggest games of all time, being streamlined as such, but for anyone unfamiliar to D&D rules, this game can still pose quite the challenge.

From the very moment players are thrust from a burning nautiloid, Baldur's Gate 3 poses a very hard task for them to accomplish. Trying to find a cure to something incurable with a loveable but somewhat unstable cast of adventurers will not be easy, but for PS5 players, there are a few cheat mods that should make the going a little less rough.

8 PolyamoryFixes

Romance As Many Companions As You Wish

  • Mod Creator: macrochiroptera
  • Mod Link

Trying to romance multiple characters in Baldur's Gate 3 , while certainly possible, usually ends in heartbreak. Heartbreak is fun! In a fictional setting. Strictly in a fictional setting. It adds to the stakes and drama of the story in ways outside the main storyline.

But for players who just can't decide between Shadowheart and Astarion, this mod removes the jealousy and reactions to attempts at romancing multiple people, which means players no longer have to make a choice and can romance whomever they'd like.

7 Inspirations Uncapped

Accrue Unlimited Inspiration

  • Mod creator: RealityThreek
  • Mod Link

Inspiration can be a powerful tool in D&D campaigns of all strokes, provided the DM remembers to hand it out more than thrice a campaign (pro DM tip - give inspiration to players who bribe you with food!), and this is no different in Baldur's Gate 3 .

Inspiration is handed out for acting in accordance with the character's backstory, but this mod removes the cap that prevents players from accruing inspiration beyond four at any time - instead, players can have as many inspiration points as they can feasibly accrue.

6 Xp-Multiplier x10

Go Through Levels At A Faster Rate

  • Mod creator: SilverExil
  • Mod Link

Baldur's Gate 3 , without other mods, caps character progression at level 12. The simple reason for this is that having a game that goes up to level 20, even if things were rebalanced so that a level 20 cap didn't increase the game length, would be ridiculously hard to balance.

It also means that players can feel as though they're moving through levels rather sluggishly, as they're fairly spaced out after level 3. This simple and unobtrusive mod should help players get through levels quicker without destroying immersion or progression.

5 Nauthiz's Godlike Armor

Trivialize Game Combat

  • Mod creator: bayonora
  • Mod link

For players who just want to focus on romance or storyline quests without getting backed up by things like combat, this armor mod provides players with an incredible armor set, well beyond even the strongest legendary armor in the vanilla game.

The AC is a ridiculous 57, and grants players an instant-death ability as well, ensuring combat is only so much fluff before the next great story beat or character moment.

4 Midas Touch - Free Gold

Go On A Shopping Spree Of Godly Proportions

  • Mod creator: Magic_Cozmo
  • Mod link

Gold in Baldur's Gate 3 stops really becoming an issue by Act 3 when an entire game's worth of questing and looting has been done. There are some ways to quickly accrue gold but for those who don't want to worry about the grind, this is the mod for them.

This mod adds a cantrip available to all classes that adds a good deal of gold to the player inventory whenever activated, making sure they'll never have to go without money again.

3 FeatsOnEvenLevels

Explore More Of What Feats Have To Offer

  • Mod creator: thekennneth
  • Mod link

Feats are a great way to diversify the player's class and build, specializing in a great number of archetypes from a polearm-wielding master to a heavily armored juggernaut. Feats are rare in the vanilla game, however.

This game gives players much more variety with the builds they can create thanks to the more frequent opportunities to get feats and diversify their build on the way to max level.

2 Infinite Potions

A Great Backup Plan For Tough Battles

  • Mod creator: BelinnFromNexusMods
  • Mod link

Alchemy is the pathway to many excellent potions in this game, as are the many chests in the world that contain game-changing effects through magical elixirs. The issue is, of course, that potions are inherently single-use thanks to the fact that they're consumables.

This mod changes how potions work so that drinking a potion doesn't consume them, functionally making them infinite. It does not work for thrown potions, though, so be warned.

1 Gale Dinners

Sacrifice Relics No More

  • Mod creator: BelinnFromNexusMods
  • Mod link

In the early game, magic items are quite rare. They have an especially important impact on the game when players are still learning the important skills from their class, and amulets or rings with spells attached can be vital to certain playstyles.

This makes Gale's hunger for magic items quite inconvenient. Fortunately, this mod adds special magic items with no purpose besides being given to Gale to sate his hunger, so players can keep their magic items without Gale taking a dark turn.

item.title: The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time â€“ Every Dungeon & Temple Ranked
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Ocarina Of Time has diverse and challenging dungeons with varying visuals and mechanics.
  • Iconic dungeons like the Water Temple are infamous for their difficulty and unique designs.
  • Final dungeon Ganon's Castle is a climactic showdown with overwhelming challenges and epic boss fights.

Often ranked as a top-tier game in the franchise, The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time is undoubtedly a bonafide classic. It featured an epic story, enchantment, horror, and adventure and changed The Legend Of Zelda for the better with brand-new 3D visuals for the time that made the world feel massive.

One way it became such a classic was through its diverse dungeons; dungeons have been a staple of Zelda since the beginning. Some are fun but challenging worlds to explore within themselves, while others have gained a more infamous reputation due to the frustration of gamers. From a visual, structure, and difficulty perspective, the Ocarina Of Time dungeons are all over the place.

Updated on November 27, 2024, by Melody MacReady: Almost three decades later, The Legend Of Zelda: Ocarina Of Time continues to be a favorite in the long line of Zelda games. That shows how much time and effort was put into making the game by Nintendo, as it not only became a favorite, it changed the direction of The Legend Of Zelda forever. The dungeons may not be what everybody immediately thinks of when it comes to The Legend Of Zelda, but they are an important piece of the puzzle that makes a beautiful picture. The dungeons and temples featured in Ocarina Of Time come in all shapes, sizes, and gimmicks to make each trek through seem fresh, particularly for first-time players.

13 The Ice Cavern

Ice Physics Makes It A Chore To Get Through

  • Location: Zora's Fountain
  • Signature Item: Iron Boots

Visually, the Ice Cavern is a very impressive dungeon and features some of the more unique enemies in Ocarina Of Time . Gameplay-wise, it features all the frustrating elements and mechanics that make most ice-based levels so frustrating in video games, from slippery floors to hazards that can freeze Link in place.

The controls for Ocarina Of Time are made for exploration and combat, not platforming. As a result, what was already frustrating for players in other dungeons is amplified in the Ice Cavern. The calming music and the puzzles are highlights, but as a whole, it is considered a chore of a dungeon to get through.

12 Gerudo Fortress

Stealth Is Frustratingly Vital In The Prison Labyrinth

  • Location: Gerudo Valley
  • Signature Item: Gerudo Token

Much like the Ice Caverns, Gerudo Fortress is impressive with how much detail Nintendo went into. With that said, it is known for being a frustrating maze with strict stealth mechanics; Link is either hiding or is spotted. There is no in-between like in Metal Gear Solid. One teeny tiny glimpse from a guard, and it's back to the prison cell to try and repeat the annoying maze of halls.

In a way, the relentless form of stealth does help sustain tension, knowing that one mistake can reset all progress. Thankfully, getting caught does not reset saving the trapped carpenters from their cells. Gerudo Fortress does give insight into the world Ganondorf originated and the culture of the Gerudo people, who have since become a staple in many versions of Hyrule across the series.

11 Gerudo Training Ground

An Optional Dungeon With A Worthwhile Reward

  • Location: Gerudo Fortress
  • Signature Item: Ice Arrows

Short and sweet, the Gerudo Training Ground is an optional dungeon hidden within the Gerudo Fortress. In it, Link is forced to go through a series of trials that test the player's knowledge of the different dungeons, as there are lava, water, invisible, and other challenges to overcome.

The reward is worth the arduous tests, as the end of the Gerudo Training Ground gifts players with Ice Arrows. Depending on when the player unlocks them, the Ice Arrows can be a useful tool in other dungeons and certain bosses, showcasing how side quests and mini-dungeons can help Link in the main story.

10 Inside Jabu-Jabu's Belly

Curing A Giant Fish Of A Parasite Can Be Tricky

  • Location: Zora's Fountain
  • Signature Item: Boomerang

Carrying a spoiled Zora princess through a living dungeon that is constantly trying to kill Link resulted in many frustrated players. On top of that, the player must avoid falling through Inside Jabu-Jabu's Belly , thus resetting tons of progress depending on how much they have accomplished.

Just to make it even better, the dungeon has one of the most frustrating bosses in the game. It's the last of the starter dungeons and it shows by setting up things to come. Visually, it is kind of disturbing since Link is basically trekking through body parts, but it's impressive at the same time.

9 Dodongo's Cavern

A Classic Cave That Continues To Teach The Player

  • Location: Death Mountain Trail
  • Signature Item: Bomb Bag

The best thing about Dodongo's Cavern is its main area containing the giant skull; it gives the dungeon a massive scope that can be intimidating. The Dodongos and Lizalfos enemies are still quite simple but can be overwhelming to first-time players trying to figure out how to get through. The dungeon has some great puzzles that require a lot of traversing, but not to the point of irritation.

The only really disappointing aspect is the final boss fight against King Dodongo, which is surprisingly easy to beat, even for an early-game boss. With that said, it is essentially a tutorial level that is meant to show off the capabilities of the bombs, which become an essential part of Link's arsenal throughout the game.

8 The Spirit Temple

Twinrova Makes A Great Dungeon Even Better

  • Location: Desert Colossus
  • Signature Items: Silver Gauntlets, Mirror Shield

The Spirit Temple is a complex one, but in a good way; it features some genuinely challenging puzzles yet utilizes light and darkness to complete puzzles. It's an improvement over the Gerudo Temple due to its interior visuals, looking akin to a tomb straight out of Ancient Egypt at times and it features a memorable boss fight.

The boss, Twinrova, is often considered the best thing about the Spirit Temple. With two different forms, which were not normal for The Legend Of Zelda games at the time, that keeps the player on their toes at all times, forcing them to utilize mirrors in dynamic ways.

7 The Water Temple

A Watery Maze That Became Infamous For Its Difficulty

  • Location: Lake Hylia
  • Signature Items: Longshot

Every person who has played Ocarina Of Time knows the horrors of the Water Temple . The constant raising and lowering of water levels with a confusing layout, and the aggravating backtracking to solve every puzzle to get to the end. It does deserve credit that a lot of thought and care was put into the Water Temple by the developers, despite the frustration.

The Water Temple was unique for its time and very few water-based dungeons have matched its design and visuals. It also features one of the standout rooms of the game; an ethereal plain that is psychedelic, beautiful, and eerie at the same time. Especially when Dark Link appears as a mini-boss, and it is a refreshing challenge since he is a near-perfect mirror of Link.

6 Inside The Great Deku Tree

Sinister Starting Dungeon Which Lays The Foundation Of What's To Come

  • Location: Kokiri Forest
  • Signature Item: Slingshot

For a Legend Of Zelda game to really draw in the player, it needs the first dungeon to be the perfect starter. Ocarina Of Time delivers that by having Link go Inside The Great Deku Tree ; it introduces the player to many central gameplay aspects, including combat complexities, puzzle-solving, and the use of items.

Normally, a tree setting would be serene, especially after Kokiri Village being such a pleasant town, but Inside The Great Deku Tree has a creepy but intriguing atmosphere, and it features a great boss to really test a first-time player's aim and reflexes. Queen Gohma is the ideal introduction to boss fights, though she may be a little much for those with arachnophobia.

5 The Shadow Temple

Undead And Monsters Thrive In The Darkest Dungeon

  • Location: Kakariko Village Graveyard
  • Signature Item: Hover Boots

Despite Ocarina Of Time being a family-friendly game, it features quite the horror-centric dungeon with the Shadow Temple . The entire temple has some of the best puzzles that require the use of the Hover Boots and Lens Of Truth to navigate, making for suspense from both the enemies and the obstacles.

The murky visuals not only help the limitations of the Nintendo 64 but make every room and corridor feel like something could jump out at any time. Sometimes that feeling is correct, sometimes it isn't, which keeps the player alert throughout the journey, aside from the boss fight against Bongo-Bongo, who doesn't fit the horror themes of the dungeon.

4 The Forest Temple

Far From A Typical Forest Level

  • Location: Sacred Forest Meadow
  • Signature Item: Fairy Bow

Forest dungeons are usually about trees, grass, and serenity, but the Forest Temple surprised newcomers by having it be about a ghost-infested temple with disorienting puzzles straight out of a haunted house ride. Every second in the temple is just ominous and designed to make gamers feel uneasy; it's filled with ghosts and monsters that can appear out of nowhere at all times.

There's also this strange feeling that the player is being watched by something, making it one of the scariest dungeons in the franchise. Combined with creepy music in the game and a solid boss against Phantom Ganon, it is a surprising first dungeon for adult Link to tackle but establishes the tone for how all the temples feel from there on out.

3 Bottom Of The Well

A Mini-Dungeon That Childhood Nightmares Spawned From

  • Location: Kakariko Village
  • Signature Item: Lens Of Truth

The Forest Temple was scary but the hidden dungeon at the Bottom Of The Well in the pleasantness of Kakariko Village is considered a nightmare by fans. Every second of this dungeon belongs to a survival horror game akin to Silent Hill . It has distinguished visuals from the Shadow Temple, purposefully confusing puzzles and traversal with undead and monsters around every corner.

The Dead Hand quickly became one of the most infamous enemies in The Legend Of Zelda history for a reason. This enemy alone is enough to make any child turn off the game and run out of the room but likely inspired a few aspiring horror writers or game designers.

2 The Fire Temple

A Gauntlet Of Fire That Never Lets Up

  • Location: Death Mountain Crater
  • Signature Item: Megaton Hammer

As taxing as it can be, the Fire Temple is one of the longest and most thrilling dungeons in Ocarina Of Time . Every room provides a constant challenge, whether it's the environment with its endless fire and lava or the various enemies, including Like Likes that can swallow important items such as the shield.

The Fire Temple also features another ominous soundtrack, sounding almost like wind with a light instrumental backing. Depending on the copy of Ocarina Of Time , there is an eerily chanting to the background music that became famous for scaring some players. In the end, it is topped off with Volvagia, a simple boss but its design is one of the more intimidating dragon designs in the series.

1 Ganon's Castle

The Climactic Showdown With Ganondorf Is A Fitting Culmination Of The Whole Game

  • Location: Hyrule Castle
  • Signature Items: Golden Gauntlets, Light Arrows

The final dungeon, Ganon's Castle , ends Ocarina Of Time with a bang; it is one giant gauntlet of every mechanic, puzzle, and item the player has experienced throughout their adventure. There are even elements of the dreaded Ice Caverns in this gauntlet, so this dungeon can get a bit overwhelming but never to the point of quitting rage.

That's all before the final boss against Ganondorf himself, which is a taxing affair in itself with three different phases. It's visually striking with everything huge and epic to make it feel like a proper climax, with plenty of build-up to the encounter against Ganondorf. One of the best details is Ganondorf's organ getting louder as Link treks up through the castle.

item.title: Luma Island: How to Find Copper Ore
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Find Copper Ore in Luma Island

Luma Island puts players in a magical world full of secrets. There are numerous mysteries to uncover in the game, but that doesn't mean you're on a timer. You can play the game at your own pace as you help out the NPCs in the town, master different professions, and gradually build up your dream farm. Throughout your journey, you'll craft many items and sell them in shops to make a profit that will help you grow your Farm.

Copper Ore is an essential crafting ingredient that you'll need for a wide variety of recipes. However, players taking their first steps into the game might find it difficult to secure a steady supply of Copper Ore early on. That's where we come in! In this guide, we'll discuss all there's to know about finding Copper Ore in Luma Island .

How to Find Copper Ore in Luma Island

Copper Ore can be found by mining Copper Ore nodes that spawn around the world of Luma Island . When you start the game, you'll find two Copper Ore nodes right beside your trailer near the Abandoned Farm Cave entrance. While exploring the Farm area, you might also find a few more Copper Ore nodes if you're lucky. However, since these nodes don't respawn once mined, you'll have a hard time locating other sources of Copper for your crafting recipes.

Copper Ore can be turned into Copper Ingots in the Ore Smelter, which are essential for building structures like the Fisherman's Galley in Luma Island .

The quickest and easiest way to get some Copper Ore is to head into the Abandoned Farm Cave using the ladder near your Farm. The Cave has plenty of Copper Ore nodes that you can mine using your Copper Pickaxe.

However, what makes things tricky is that, apart from the initial area, the rest of the Cave is completely dark. If you stay in the dark for too long, you'll die and have to restart from the Cave entrance. Thankfully, you don't lose any of your items, but you still can't really mine any Copper Ore. You'll need to make some Farm Torches to navigate the Abandoned Farm Cave without dying. For that, you'll have to buy the Simple Workbench Blueprint from Blathazar's Drawing Shop in the Town outskirts.

The Simple Workbench requires 3x Farm Wood and 5x Twigs to build.

Once you build a Simple Workbench, you can craft Farm Torches from it. You can get 2 Torches from 1x Farm Wood and 1x Farm Resin, both of which are pretty easily available around the Farm. Stock up on at least 10 Farm Torches and head into the Abandoned Farm Cave. Place the Torches on the ground as you progress through the Cave, and you'll come across plenty of Copper Ore nodes that you can mine to stock up on Copper Ore.

You can also mine Charcoal, Bronze, or other minerals in this Cave.

However, while mining, remember to keep track of your surroundings. If you stay inside the cave for too long, Spiders will start spawning that will attack you on sight. They can be killed using the Whip. However, since you aren't likely to have your tools upgraded, they can be pretty hard to take down during the early hours of Luma Island.

item.title: Mobile Games With The Best Graphics
item.description: When Apple unveiled the iPhone 15, it signaled significant shifts in the landscape of mobile gaming. Players are now in an era where they can play award-winning AAA console games like Resident Evil 4 Remake on a smartphone, with features like ray tracing. In turn, gamers now have higher graphical expectations for their mobile games. If youâ€™re wondering what games have the best visual effects that could rival those found in console games, then we're here to tell you 10 of the Best Mobile Games with the Best Graphics.

item.title: 9 RPG Franchises That Drastically Change Gameplay Over Time
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Iconic RPG franchises have evolved by incorporating RPG elements, skill systems, and deeper narratives.
  • Changes in gameplay have attracted wider audiences but sometimes moved away from traditional roots.
  • Flexibility in RPG mechanics and adaptation to market demands contribute to the longevity and cultural impact of the genre.

The RPG genre has undergone significant transformations over the decades, adapting to trends in the video game industry. Iconic franchises have reshaped their mechanics, expanding the scope of their gaming experiences and, on some occasions, distancing themselves from their traditional roots. Hybridization with other genres, such as action and adventure, has resulted in innovative systems and more dynamic narratives, attracting a wider audience.

On the other hand, various series originally not associated with the genre have incorporated RPG elements like skill trees and deeper narratives, expanding the reach and diversity of the experience. This exchange of characteristics demonstrates how the genre's flexibility contributes to its longevity, offering experiences adapted to market demands while maintaining its cultural impact at the heart of the video game industry.

9 Assassin's Creed

Ubisoft Gradually Added RPG Elements To The Franchise

Known for historical exploration, parkour, and stealth, Assassin's Creed in its early titles, such as Assassin's Creed and Assassin's Creed 2 , offered linear narratives and well-structured missions. These games maintained a classic action-adventure approach, emphasizing historical accuracy and the development of the Assassins' storyline.

In more recent releases like Valhalla and Odyssey , the series incorporated RPG elements, including character customization, skill systems, and decisions that influence the narrative. This integration of RPG mechanics expanded the depth and complexity of the gameplay, bringing innovations for players who enjoy these mechanics but also moving away from the series' roots.

8 Mass Effect

Bioware Made Major Changes To The Franchise's Formula

The Mass Effect franchise evolved considerably in its gameplay across titles. Mass Effect 1 combined classic RPG elements with deep exploration and a rich narrative, focusing on character development and player choices. However, some side missions were less appealing due to monotony.

With Mass Effect 2 , the series adopted a more action-oriented approach, similar to third-person shooters, simplifying traditional RPG aspects to attract a wider audience, something that continued in the third game. In Mass Effect: Andromeda , the series attempted to return to its exploration and role-playing roots but faced technical issues that compromised the player experience.

7 Fallout

From Classic Isometric RPGs To 3D Games

Since its inception, Fallout has remained one of the great classics of the video game industry, even with significant transformations in gameplay over the years. The first two games were isometric RPG classics, featuring turn-based combat and choice-laden narratives, with exploration connecting the world map to enclosed areas.

However, with Fallout 3 , the franchise migrated to 3D environments with first or third-person perspectives, adopting elements of RPG, action, and open-world gameplay, which became a hallmark of the series. The V.A.T.S. system allowed a mix of classic gameplay with new features added by Bethesda, and Fallout 4 introduced further changes with a greater emphasis on exploration.

6 The Witcher

The Games Always Introduce Something New

The Witcher franchise is one of the RPGs that shows a remarkable evolution in both gameplay mechanics and design philosophy throughout its main titles. The first game featured timing-based combat and limited map exploration, while the second advanced the formula with dynamic fights and larger environments, even though the structure of both was similar.

However, in The Witcher 3 , Geralt's saga reached its peak, becoming an open-world RPG with continuous exploration, refined combat, and a level of freedom not seen in previous games of the franchise. This transformation solidified the series as one of the industry's milestones but also raised the bar for the genre.

5 Persona

A JRPG That Remains Quite Traditional

The first two Persona games are completely different from the modern entries, showing how gameplay has changed since the franchise's debut by incorporating new elements that redefined the gameplay style. The original games featured classic JRPG mechanics, with dungeon exploration and turn-based combat, but without the social systems that now define the franchise.

Starting with Persona 3 , the franchise transformed by introducing mechanics like Social Links and slightly reformulating the combat gameplay, which maintained the essence already known to fans but also brought changes to make the gameplay more fluid. Through this evolution, the series became even more popular, attracting new audiences without losing older fans.

4 Final Fantasy

A JRPG That Has Undergone Many Changes Throughout History

The Final Fantasy franchise is one of the most iconic in the video game industry, marking generations with its innovations. The early titles, featuring pixel art and turn-based combat, defined the foundations of the JRPG genre, presenting engaging narratives and strategic systems that became references for future games.

With the transition to 3D, the series began to explore more dynamic and action-oriented combat systems, as seen in recent titles. This evolution reflects not only technological changes but also the desire to meet the demands of an ever-changing audience, consolidating Final Fantasy as a franchise that shapes and follows the game market.

3 Dragon Age

Each Game Has Its Own Gameplay

Few RPG franchises have undergone as many gameplay changes as Dragon Age , with every game released in the series so far possessing something that makes them unique. The first, for example, was more focused on CRPG, with real-time combat with pauses, but the second and third added new elements or changed everything.

In Dragon Age: Inquisition , new changes were added, transforming the gameplay once again. The combat became more action-focused, allowing control of only the protagonist during fights, while map exploration also changed, with smaller and more linear regions to be discovered.

2 Yakuza

A Franchise That Adopted RPG Elements Over Time

In contrast to many franchises that abandoned RPG roots over time in favor of more action-focused gameplay, Yakuza took the opposite path, as the series' origins are in beat 'em ups, but currently, it is a reference among traditional JRPGs. This happened and was also justified by the change in the saga's protagonist.

So, despite being set in a contemporary setting, the new Yakuza JRPGs make small parodies or homages to classic elements of the genre, such as the fact that classes, or jobs as they are called in other games, are learned in employment agencies. Another interesting fact is that when Kiryu, the former protagonist, is on the scene, the gameplay adapts to the classic style of the series.

1 Baldurâ€™s Gate

A Series That Always Remained Among The Classics

From its conception as an isometric RPG with real-time combat with pauses to the transformation it underwent in Baldur's Gate 3 , becoming a turn-based game, this is one of the franchises that managed to maintain game consistency even with changes in gameplay. Thus, players of different generations could experience all the content offered.

Baldur's Gate 3 exemplifies the ability of RPG franchises to reinvent themselves, adopting turn-based combat and a deep narrative without abandoning the roots and aspects that made the series a classic. This evolution not only attracted new audiences but also strengthened the series' legacy, highlighting flexibility as a key element for the longevity of RPG games.
